77.heading: Panels.
77.title: A Visual Lexicon
77.author: by Neil Cohn.
notes: Paper presented at the Comics Arts Conference, July 14-17, 2005, San Diego, Calif.

"The most recognized unit in visual language is the 'panel,' though meaningful units do exist that are both smaller and larger than panels. This is similar to spoken languages, where lexical items can be both above or below the level of the 'word.' This paper will address these varying levels of representation in visual languge to lead toward a general understanding of what it means to have 'visual lexical items.'"

88.title: Pàng the Wandering Shàolín Monk ; v. 1 Refuge of the Heart
88.author: by Ben Costa.
88.genre: Kung fu and adventure story genres.
notes: "The year is 1675. Caught up in a conflict he barely understands, a portly Buddhist warrior monk named Shì Lóng Pàng sets out to find his brothers after the destruction of their temple at the hands of the Qîng dynasty."

89.title: Pàng the Wandering Shàolín Monk ; v. 2 Winter Worm, Summer Grass
89.author: by Ben Costa.
notes: "Fresh on the heels of his recent misadventures, and his recent dalliance in town, Shì Lóng Páng, the portly Buddhist warrior monk, continues the search for his brothers, armed with a greater resolve than ever before. But as he tries to find his way in an unforgiving landscape during a tumultuous period in Chinese history, he'll have to further wrestle with what it means to be a monk outside the temple, and what it takes to survive in a world full of ferocious predators, drunken masters, and startling discoveries."

124.title: Panhandle Pete
124.author: [No author]
124.series: July 1951) "Meet Panhandle Pete" 1 p. text in Panhandle Pete and Jennifer, no. 1
notes: "If you live within reach of television's coaxial cable, you can see Pete on the screen as he relates his stories to Miss Jennifer, a neighbor of his in Chickamoochie County. On the show, Pete is played by Johnny Coons, Jennifer by Jennifer Holt. Stories are written by Ray Chan, and illustrations by William Newton and Stan Louis. They also wrote and drew this book."

125.title: Panhandle Pete
125.author: Bill Newton
125.appears_in: 12 p. in Panhandle Pete and Jennifer, no. 1 (July 1951).
notes: Summary: Pete and his burro, George Burro, were prospecting in 1878 when they found a friendly dinosaur named Dennis. They start a circus and rake in money. Taint Right, the swindler, tries to buy Dennis, then tries to trick Dennis away by showing him a girl dinosaur (made of cardboard). A lovestruck Dennis breaks loose and heads for the hills looking for the girl dinosaur, and they never see him again. Every time Pete and George see heat lightning, they think it might be Dennis, still searching.

126.title: Panhandle Pete
126.author: Stan Louis
126.appears_in: 12 p. in Panhandle Pete and Jennifer, no. 2 (Sept. 1951).
notes: Summary: Pete buys a strange machine from Rapid Jack Rabbit, the drummer (salesman). He tells a story of the old days when they were prospecting, with Jack trying to sell them tents, parasols and ice cream. They struck gold, but gave it all to Jack for water.

127.title: Panhandle Pete
127.author: Bill Newton
127.appears_in: 9 p. in Panhandle Pete and Jennifer, no. 2 (Sept. 1951).
notes: Summary: The Coyote Kid trades his sombrero for a file, and gets out of jail only to get stuck in a rain barrel. He then digs out of jail through the floor and runs, only to have a cyclone pick up the jail and drop it on him.
Panhandle Pete and Li'l Wigwam are in the story as humans, and the Kid and Pancho are funny animals.

164.appears_in: 4 p. in Strange Tales, no. 95 (Apr. 1962) ; reprinted in Monsters on the Prowl, no. 26 (Oct. 1973) ; reprinted again in Curse of the Weird, no. 1 (Dec. 1993).
notes: Summary: An alien craft arrives over a city and descends. The pilot wears a frightening spacesuit, but since the military do not panic, they do not attack. When the human pilot removes his helmet he is warmly greeted by the people of Mars.
Data from Bob Klein, Lou Mougin, Martin O'Hearn, et al. via Grand Comics Database.

165.heading: Panic.
165.title: "Earth is Off-Limits!"
165.author: script, Stan Lee ; art, Steve Ditko ; letters, Artie Simek
notes: Summary: Explorers discover life on a far-off planet, but mission control panics at the thought of alien germs loose on Earth and forbids them to return. The crew tries to explain, but mission control breaks the communication as they cannot bear to listen to their pleas. What the explorers were trying to say was that the life on the planet grants disease immunity and long life span.
Data from Bob Klein, Lou Mougin, Martin O'Hearn, et al. via Grand Comics Database.

166.heading: Panic.
166.title: "Eddie Foy, a Hero of the Theatre" p. 42-47 in Real Heroes, no. 3
166.author: [No author]
notes: Clown Eddie Foy tried with partial success to keep a crowd from panicking during a fire at the Iroquois Theatre in Chicago, Dec. 30, 1903.

167.heading: Panic.
167.title: "False Alarm"
167.author: [No author]
167.series: Blondie) 4 p. in Blondie Comics, no. 126
notes: Summary (by Amy Lazet): Dagwood is snacking before bed, but Blondie tells him he will sleep better if he doesn't. Dagwood disagrees, since snacking gives him vivid, colorful dreams. He has a bowl of spaghetti, and dreams of kings and flying and beautiful maidens, until Blondie awakens him in a panic. The alarm never went off! She sends Daisy the dog to wake the children while she hustles Dagwood along. After a frantic flurry of activity, Dagwood and the children leave for work and school. Suddenly, Daisy and Blondie notice the newspaper on the stoop. It's Sunday! "Be brave, Daisy," Blondie murmurs as they clutch each other in nervous apprehension while Dagwood and the kids storm furiously back into the house.

171.heading: Panic.
171.title: "L'Homme des Montagnes Bleues"
171.author: [No author]
171.series: Giddap Joe) p. 99-130 in Cap'tain Swing, no. 114
notes: Summary: The story opens at "Terre Brulée," the ranch of Giddap Joe. An Indian boy named Wa Wa is hauling water for the horses when he comes upon White Deer, a girl who brings a warning. The white man in the blue mountains must leave, she says, or he will be killed. There are only 15 days until winter snow is expected. Joe takes the warning seriously, and rides up into the mountains to look for the man. The man turns out to be Bruce Altman, an old friend. It starts to snow early, and the two are stuck in Altman's cabin for the winter. Altman's story is that he was out hunting with his young son Tom, six years earlier, when Tom saw an Indian, panicked, and killed her. She was out picking berries. Bruce told Tom never to admit he did it, and Bruce took the blame for the crime himself. The incident led to the killing of two other white families by the Indians. The people of the town, Lone Pine, were about to lynch Bruce as the cause of the Indian attacks, so he went into hiding. Unbeknownst to Bruce, Tom has stood up in church and told the truth within the past year, to clear his father's name. The brother of the dead girl is still hunting Bruce, but Giddap intercedes and explains the situation to the brother. Bruce goes home.
